author: John Cross
title: Chelsea's Kurt Zouma on how living up to his unusual middle name helped recovery from horror injury
text:
Sport Chelsea's Kurt Zouma on how living up to his unusual middle name helped recovery from horror injury French defender given the Happy moniker by his dad needed trademark sunny disposition during nearly a year out with knee ligament damage Share "You see me laughing every time, everywhere — for nothing. That's my character" (Photo: Daily Mirror/Philip Coburn) Share Get Chelsea FC updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
You will not find a footballer with a bigger smile than Kurt Zouma . 
In fact, Happy is his middle name. 
Yes, really. 
And the Chelsea defender definitely lives up to his name. 
And at the moment, Kurt Happy Zouma - to use his full name - has got plenty to smile about as he is back to full fitness to help Chelsea’s push for the Premier League title. 
“Yeah, it’s true,” laughs the Frenchman. “It was my father. 
"When my mother was pregnant, my father was watching a Van Damme movie. He was killing everybody and fighting everyone. 
“And my father said, ‘Yeah, this one we’re going to call him Kurt [Van Damme plays Kurt Sloane in the 1989 movie Kickboxer] because he’s going to be strong and Happy because he’s going to laugh every time.’ And if the story of his MIDDLE name isn't enough, Zouma got his first from a Van Damme film! 
“Now when I see them I say, ‘Daddy, I respect you. Every time I laugh and I’m big and strong. Thank you, Dad.’ 
“I am a happy character. Every time, I laugh. You see me laughing every time everywhere, for nothing. You say ‘ABC’, I’m gonna laugh. I fall on the floor. I don’t know why. That’s my character.” 
It was smiling and having a sense of humour which helped him through the dark days of being out for eight months with a cruciate knee ligament injury. 
Zouma is back in the Chelsea set-up, starting FA Cup games and pushing to start in the Premier League after coming on as a substitute against Arsenal last Saturday. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Kurt Zouma and N'Golo Kante get the giggles Share this video Watch Next 
“If you are mentally good, your recovery is going to be better and quicker,” said Zouma. “That’s my philosophy. 
“If you give up and you’re sad every day you’re going to struggle. I keep laughing. I’m still young, enjoy the life. I’m a footballer, I have a great life. So let’s laugh.” 
Zouma was a mainstay in Chelsea’s last title-winning team and was named their Young Player of the Year. But 12 months ago he ruptured his anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee. 
The France international centre-half stands 6ft 3in tall — and looks about 6ft wide. Throwing shapes with Michy Batshuayi during the recent FA Cup win over Brentford (Photo: Getty) Read More Marcos Alonso insists he didn't foul Bellerin on THAT goal against Arsenal 
While some players cannot bear to watch replays of when they suffer bad injuries, there was no such reticence from Zouma. 
“Not me. I’m not scared to watch. I don’t care,” he said. “It’s very difficult when someone tells you that you’re going to be out for nine or 10 months. 
“When I saw the images I knew it was going to be long. But in my mind I said, ‘OK, this is the injury, you’re 22, so do a good rehab, recover well and when you come back you will have plenty of time to play many games.’” 
It has been a remarkable career for the former St Etienne defender. It's almost exactly a year since Zouma was injured against Manchester United (Photo: Man Utd via Getty) Read More Kante insists Chelsea aren't taking title for granted and will "fight for every game" 
He won the title in his first season at Chelsea under Jose Mourinho and is on course to get another with Antonio Conte. 
Zouma still has a huge respect for Mourinho and Conte taking him on the club’s US pre-season tour last summer is just typical of the current Chelsea boss’s ­brilliant man management. 
Zouma added: “My first year at Chelsea we won the Capital One Cup and then the Premier League. I was dreaming. But managers go. It’s part of football. I don’t feel guilty. Mourinho’s gone, let’s think about the future. 
“It was a bad season, now we are doing well again. Conte loves what he does. He wants to give that special feeling to us. We need to love football like he does, to breathe football. That’s what he wants. Although obviously EVERYONE is this happy to meet John Cross... (Photo: Daily Mirror/Philip Coburn) Read More Juan Cuadrado's mum revealed she 'prayed' for her son to leave Chelsea 
“I was really pleased when I learned I was going to America. I didn’t know him (Conte) before, he didn’t know me. He’d just watched me in the odd game on TV, but just one or two times maybe. Then he said he trusted me. Those words made a difference. 
“He’s a really nice guy. He thinks, eats and sleeps football. He talks football, everything is football with him. He’s so passionate and he wants to give that to the players. 
“Tactically we watch a lot of videos and we learn. Details are important to him. 
He says ‘You can’t be there, you need to be there because if the ball goes over you there you’re dead, so just anticipate.’ 
“You learn a lot with him, a lot. The Italian style is very good for defenders.” Like us on Facebook
